topic_name: Measures of Central Tendency for Grouped Data

canonical_explanation.text: Measures of central tendency for grouped data include mean, median, and mode. The mean can be calculated using three methods: (1) Direct method: Mean = Σ(f×x)/Σf where x is the class mark and f is frequency, (2) Assumed-mean method: Mean = A + Σ(f×d)/Σf where A is assumed mean and d = x - A, (3) Step-deviation method: Mean = A + [Σ(f×u)/Σf] × h where u = (x-A)/h and h is class width. The median is the middle value when data is arranged in order, calculated using the formula: Median = L + [(N/2 - cf)/f] × h, where L is lower boundary of median class, N is total frequency, cf is cumulative frequency before median class, f is frequency of median class, and h is class width. It can also be found graphically using an ogive (cumulative frequency curve). The mode is the most frequently occurring value, calculated using the formula: Mode = L + [(f₁ - f₀)/(2f₁ - f₀ - f₂)] × h, where L is lower boundary of modal class, f₁ is frequency of modal class, f₀ is frequency of class before modal class, f₂ is frequency of class after modal class, and h is class width. Mode can also be determined from a histogram by drawing lines from the tops of the modal class to the adjacent bars.
rules: For mean calculations, class mark x = (lower limit + upper limit)/2
Choose assumed mean A preferably as the class mark of the middle class for easier calculations
Step-deviation method is most efficient when class widths are equal and frequencies are large numbers
Median class is the class where cumulative frequency first exceeds or equals N/2
Modal class is the class with the highest frequency
In an ogive, median corresponds to the x-value at y = N/2
Less than ogive uses upper class boundaries; greater than ogive uses lower class boundaries
For interpretation, consider context: mean is affected by extreme values, median is positional, mode shows most common value
Always verify that Σf equals the total number of observations
Class width h must be consistent in step-deviation and median/mode formulas

options.text: The class with the highest frequency
The class where cumulative frequency first exceeds or equals N/2
The middle class in the frequency distribution
The class with the lowest frequency

options.text: The class with the lowest frequency
The class with the highest frequency
The class at the center of the distribution

questions.question_text: What does the modal class represent in a frequency distribution?
For a grouped frequency distribution with class intervals of equal width 10, if the assumed mean A = 45 and Σ(f×u)/Σf = 2.4, what is the mean using step-deviation method?
In a frequency distribution, the median class is 30-40 with f = 12, cf = 25, N = 50, and h = 10. What is the median?
If the modal class is 25-35 with f₁ = 20, f₀ = 12, f₂ = 8, and h = 10, what is the mode?
The mean of a grouped frequency distribution is 52. If the assumed mean A = 50 and the class width h = 5, what is the value of Σ(f×u)/Σf in the step-deviation method?
An ogive is drawn for a frequency distribution of 100 observations. At what cumulative frequency value should a horizontal line be drawn to find the median?

options.text: The distribution is positively skewed with some high-income outliers

questions.question_text: In interpreting statistical results for income distribution, the mean is Rs. 45,000, median is Rs. 35,000, and mode is Rs. 28,000. What does this indicate about the distribution?
In the step-deviation method, the variable u is calculated as u = (x - A)/_____, where h represents the class width.
The class mark (x) of a class interval is calculated as x = (lower limit + upper limit)/_____.
In the median formula for grouped data, L represents the _____ boundary of the median class.
A _____ than ogive is drawn using the upper class boundaries and cumulative frequencies.
If the class interval 40-50 has a lower limit of 40 and upper limit of 50, the class mark is _____.
If total frequency N = 80, the median corresponds to the cumulative frequency value of _____.
Using the assumed-mean method with A = 35, if Σ(f×d) = 120 and Σf = 40, the mean is _____.
In a histogram, the mode can be found by drawing lines from the top corners of the _____ class to the adjacent bars and finding their intersection point.
For a distribution where mean = 68, median = 65, and mode = 62, the distribution is _____ skewed.
If in the mode formula, f₁ = 25, f₀ = 18, f₂ = 15, L = 50, and h = 10, then (f₁ - f₀)/(2f₁ - f₀ - f₂) × h equals _____.
The direct method for calculating mean of grouped data uses the formula Mean = Σ(f×x)/Σf.
In the assumed-mean method, any value can be chosen as the assumed mean A.
The median class is always the class with the highest frequency.
A 'less than' ogive is drawn by plotting cumulative frequencies against lower class boundaries.
The step-deviation method is most efficient when all class intervals have equal width.
In a frequency distribution, if the mean is less than the median, the distribution is positively skewed.
The mode can be determined from a histogram by identifying the tallest bar and finding its class mark.
The median obtained from an ogive and the median calculated using the formula will always give exactly the same result.
If all three measures (mean, median, mode) are equal, the distribution is perfectly symmetric.
In the mode formula, if f₀ and f₂ are equal, the mode equals the class mark of the modal class.
Match the methods of calculating mean with their respective formulas.
Match the statistical terms with their definitions.
Match the variable symbols with their meanings in the median formula.

Multiply each class mark by its frequency

questions.question_text: Arrange the steps to calculate mean using the direct method in correct order.

ordering_items: Calculate N/2 where N is total frequency
Calculate cumulative frequencies for all classes
Identify the median class where cumulative frequency ≥ N/2
Note L, f, cf, and h for the median class
Apply formula: Median = L + [(N/2 - cf)/f] × h

Calculate N/2 where N is total frequency
Identify the median class where cumulative frequency ≥ N/2
Note L, f, cf, and h for the median class
Apply formula: Median = L + [(N/2 - cf)/f] × h

ordering_items: Apply formula: Mode = L + [(f₁ - f₀)/(2f₁ - f₀ - f₂)] × h

Calculate the mode value

Note the frequencies f₀ (before), f₁ (modal), f₂ (after)
Note L (lower boundary) and h (class width) of modal class
Apply formula: Mode = L + [(f₁ - f₀)/(2f₁ - f₀ - f₂)] × h
Calculate the mode value

ordering_items: Draw a horizontal line from N/2 on y-axis
Calculate N/2 (half of total frequency)
Draw the less than ogive by plotting cumulative frequencies
Mark the point where horizontal line meets the ogive
Draw a perpendicular to x-axis from intersection point to read median

Calculate N/2 (half of total frequency)
Draw a horizontal line from N/2 on y-axis

ordering_items: Calculate d = x - A for each class

ordering_items: Apply formula: Mean = A + [Σ(f×u)/Σf] × h
Choose assumed mean A and determine class width h
Calculate step-deviation u = (x - A)/h for each class
Calculate Σ(f×u) by summing all f×u values
Multiply each u by its frequency f to get f×u
correct_answer: Choose assumed mean A and determine class width h
Calculate step-deviation u = (x - A)/h for each class
Multiply each u by its frequency f to get f×u
Calculate Σ(f×u) by summing all f×u values
Apply formula: Mean = A + [Σ(f×u)/Σf] × h

ordering_items: Draw a line from top-right corner of modal bar to top-right of previous bar
